Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2009 04:03PM Mocity wrote: Lainey, My nails have been awful but then others don't have ANY nail problems.... so if I was you I would try not to worry about it until something happens.  My Onc said it is a small % that has these types of problems with their nails and he is a leader here in the Houston medical center so I would think most times he doesn't see this.  SO most likely you will be in that category.  I hope so!
Posts.Title: TAXOL side effects? debisongbird debisongbird

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2009 02:26PM Mocity wrote: I am in a similar situation.  My Onc said it is very rare with 12 weekly Taxol's.  After week 7 my nail beds starting hurting on my hands and feet.  My big toenails started turning black and lifting... so painful.  Now I had #12 last week.  I had to go to a podiatrist and one big toenail had to come off.  Now the other one has been drained and will come off soon.   Have gone to 2 dermatologistrs about my nails... basically I just have to wait it out.  Two of my nails are lifting, another two are dark brown/purple and all are so painful.  She gave me some cream that is suppose to help with the throbbing and calm down the nail beds and I am suppose to do vinegar soaks to help keep infection out.  Also, started me on a antibiotic.  I am praying to keep some fingernails... those two toennails are lost.  How long will this last?  I know it will take a long time fo rthem to look normal but they hurt like hell.
Posts.Title: TAXOL side effects? debisongbird debisongbird

Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2011 10:43AM Mocity wrote: Hang in there...........waiting for answers, figuring out what questions to ask and making decisions are one of the hardest parts.  Once you have some answers and can put a plan in place you will feel more at ease... or at least I did.  I have met some wonderful women on these boards and the support was priceless.
Posts.Title: Need to Join - Got My Results rjbaby69 rjbaby69

Posts.Content: Mocity wrote: I had my bi-lateral mastectomy on Sept 16th and still recovering.  My pathology report came back with .4cm of IDC and here I thought I had just DCIS.  ARG!  Every since hearing the word chemo I am a complete basket case.  I need to be focusing on recovering from my BLM and am having a hard time with that too.  In fact, they didn't want to do my first fill yesterday because I was so upset and down after hearing from the Oncologist.   Can someone help me change my attitude????   I KNOW I need a good one.  I do know that.  I am so scared.  I know it could be so mcuh worse and many ladies would probably just laugh at this and tell me to get over myself.  But I am terrified.  My mom died at 38 years old from BC and I saw what the chemo and meds did to her.  Now I understand that was the early 80's but still!   He is suggested Taxol once a week for 12 weeks and Herceptin at the same time.  However, I would take the Herceptin for a full year.  Then they were talking about anotehr med to supress my ovaries production for 2 years.  Then I will be around 41 and he hopes I might be able to have a baby and have this behind me.   He is hoping by doing it every week at a lower dose the side effects won't be as bad and wont have such a bad effect on my ovaries as well.   So scared, Cristl Pathology from Bi-Lateral showed IDC (.4cm) in same breast as DCIS and nodes negative Dx 6/25/2008, IDC, <1cm, Stage I, 0/0 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Chemo is scaring me so badly. Please help me. Mocity nanclee

Posts.Content: May 2, 2009 08:32AM Mocity wrote: I finished chemo 3 months ago and finally the neuropathy seems to be gone.  However, my finger and toenails suffered.  My toes were so painful.  I lost all but one nail.  The big toenails were so painful and are totally gone.  I think they may be growing but so slow and so ugly.  No cute sandals for me this year.  I lost 2 fingernails.  All the others browned and the lifted away from my nail bed.  I am just slowly waiting for them to grow out.  I feel like a chia pet waiting for all these things to grow out.  Good luck to all
Posts.Title: Finger/fingernail problems? How common? Texas357 Texas357

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2011 10:58PM - edited Jul 20, 2011 10:58PM by Mocity I was also HER2+++ and like others said.... good news/bad news... it means it is aggressive but it also means it responds to drugs.  The good news is we know about it.  I did a year of Herceptin and it was very doable.  Nothing like chemo.  Let's thank God for that.
Posts.Title: ER+, PR+, HER2+++, are they bad news? stcc Mocity

Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2008 10:56PM Mocity wrote: So what is up with mine?  I am on my 6th week and my face is broken out all over.  Here I am at 37 buying all kinds of creams and stuff to help it.  I have been buying the opposite type of stuff until the chemo.  UGH!
Posts.Title: Chemo cleared up my acne! Emily2008 plakatakr

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2011 07:12AM Mocity wrote: I hesitated on posting because what I have learned from my moms cancer, my dads cancer and my cancer is that everyone's situation is different and all have to make our own hard decisions.  While we all have similar situations we never know what our "journey" will be so really you just have to decide what is best for you at the time.  I was diagnosed in June 2008 and had a bilateral mastectomy in Sept 2008.  I waited a bit beause I was making a decision about a bilateral but did feel guilty for waiting.  My surgeon told me it was fine to take my time with a decision.  I had my surgery and thought I was dealing with DCIS which was bad but also felt i had dodged somewhat of a bullet and wouldn 't have to have chemo.  When I had my surgery they found a small tumor outside the duct.  I ended up having chemo because of my risk - age, family history and HER2+++.  I think you just need to make a decision on what you want to do and then stick to it.  If you want to go on vacation just go and I dont think that is selfish.  You just have to make your own decision that you feel ok with.  If you want to go .. then set up your plan for afterwards and go on your vacation.  Just wanted to share my experience... sorry you are in this situation..... Hang in there,
Posts.Title: AM I REALLY THAT STUPID?? NEED LOTS OF ADVICE! rn4babies rn4babies

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2009 03:47PM - edited Sep 1, 2009 03:48PM by Mocity Laura - The lash thing is so irritating. I hated losing my eyelashes.... twice! They did grow back fairly quickly once they started though. I also had very long lashes before all this. Mine seem to be coming back now better than the first time. So just hang in there! Chelev - I have gotten the Mia Farrow reference a couple of times as well! Goldie - I did end up doing a relaxer on my curls. I went to the hairdresser Friday night and he convinced me. I was worried that it would cause my fine hair too much damage. However, he suggested what he called a "reverse perm". He said it is lighter than a actual relaxer. He said they use to do them alot when perms were a big thing. If the perm was too tight they would put this paste on the hair. So, it really did relax these tight pin curls I had. It is still wavy and curly in parts but the front will lay down now and it is easier to get it straighted. My hair is just growing so slowly. It is mostly 2 in but 3 in in some places. My bangs are growing sooo slow. I am still wearing this darn wig to work. I have been out and about now in the evenings and on the weekends but I just hate how I look. It will be coming off soon. Take care all!

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2009 12:33PM - edited Jan 12, 2009 12:34PM by Mocity Spring, No I don't think it is.  A friend of mine used it for another issue and said it works good.  It is a conditioner that you put on the lash line.  Sounds kind of like a liquid liner.  It is a little expensive.  Every I could find it at $150 including the website.  Here is the story:  The RevitaLash Story It all began because a husband wanted to give his wife a very special gift... RevitaLashTM was developed by Dr. Michael Brinkenhoff as a special gift for his wife, Gayle, while she was recovering from breast cancer. Intensive chemotherapy treatments had damaged Gayle's once-beautiful eyelashes, leaving them sparse, breakable and fragile. After extensive research with a team of talented cosmetic chemists, Dr. Brinkenhoff formulated an eyelash conditioner that, after just a few weeks, gave a renewed look of vitality to Gayle's eyelashes. Soon friends and family wanted to know Gayle's secret to beautiful looking eyelashes. Gayle knew immediately the perfect name for the amazing eyelash conditioner that had given her eyelashes a renewed look of vitality: RevitaLashTM. Thus, a new product was born; and a formula created originally for just one special woman has become a product available to women everywhere who want to have beautiful looking eyelashes. Gayle and Michael are committed to donating a portion of the proceeds from RevitaLashTM sales to benefit non-profit breast cancer research and education initiatives. "Often we feel helpless when someone we love is suffering. I am very fortunate, in my own small way, to have been able to help Gayle through her recovery. Watching her be excited about her beautiful looking eyelashes has been a real joy." - Michael Brinkenhoff, M.D. Home|Revitalash Seal|The Story|About Us|Questions?|Testimonials|Customer Care|Sales Opportunities|Contact Us|Sitemap Copyright © 2008 Athena Cosmetics Corp. Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2009 08:05PM Mocity wrote: Nodapearl, I lost my eyelashes a couple of weeks after I completed chemo.  Then I just lost them again last month.  They are back now.  The second time they didn't all fall out ... but most did.   They seemed to come back quicker than the first time though.  I am hoping there isn't a third time. Yes, this patience thing has become very important.  I tried to "fix" my hair tonight to go over to my boyfriends without the wig.  Normally I wear it over there and then take it off.  So it is a small step.  :-) Everyone have a relaxing Saturday night!

I am worried abotu damage but he said it will be a "light" one just to relax them a bit.

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2008 06:59PM Mocity wrote: Hi Carol,  I just started last week and it is good to at least have the first one behind me.  Now I am scared of losing my hair.  I can't believe it is happening.  But we can't finish until we start, right?  Now at least I am on my way to counting it down and so will you.  I had my port put in my arm last week.  I am going weekly and my next one is this Thursday. I am sure your walks help!  Everything I have read said it does and I am sure it also helps with all this stress.  I am trying to get myself worked into going on walks and am having a hard time. I am scared too.  I keep telling reminding myself of all the brave women that have been through it and we will make it too.  I am trying to be positive.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2008 12:31PM Mocity wrote: I am sitting here reading (should be working) and just going nuts.  It is day 12 for me after my first treatment.  I am goign weekly and my third will be tomorrow.  I am just in this waiting game for my hair to go.  I am just miserable thinking about it.  I keep telling myself that it is only hair and will grow back but right now it isn't helping.  Strand here and strand there.  I have very fine, thin hair already.  How did you all deal with the anxiety of this waiting?
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2008 05:19PM Mocity wrote: I agree... bad enough to go through all this and have to LOOK sick.  For all they know my cancer is gone and I felt fine.  Now the chemo is making me tired and grouchy and now just waiting and waiting to lose the hair and then wait and wait for it to grow back.  I am just in a bummer mood today knowing my hair is about to fall out. Thanks Wish and Springtime for the responses.  The anticipation of all this has me going in circles.  Waiting on the bi-lateral was hard, waiting on chemo and waiting on the hair.  UGH!  Now I am more concerned with my hair than my foobs.  I have only gotten expanded twice since my surgery on Sept 16th.  Many are done by now.  But I figure I can't have the surgery until Chemo is done so why rush the process. I have prepared for the hair loss... I think.  I have FOUR wigs ready.  My hairdresser bought me a human hair wig that looks pretty darn good.  I just don't want to be bald underneath.  Then I went and bought 3 since insurance paid for them and they are pretty good too.  One crazy one but the others look like my hair for the most part (although better I think - BUT I want my own hair).  I did buy one sleep cap but wasn't too sure what I would like. I am not married but have a serious boyfriend.  I stay with him almost every night.  He is so supportive and trys to tell me the baldness won't bother him.  What man wants to sleep with someone who is bald and boobless.  I know it will all pass and things will return to some sort of normal.  I keep telling myself the final version of my boobs will probably look better than the originals and my hair will grow back. Ok, thanks for letting me rant.  I hope everyone's hair grows back beautiful!
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Nov 25, 2008 10:18AM Mocity wrote: Thanks to all.... even worse today.  A ton came out in the shower this mroning and now I am shedding.  I had to come to work because I have chemo tomorrow (off work) because they are closed for the holiday.  Everyone is concerned with the holidays and I just want to hide. I am contemplating going to my hairdresser after work today and getting him to cut it and put the wig on that he has gotten me.  He was going to cut it and style it once again before sending me out with it.  It is hard to bring myself to go there and do that.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Nov 25, 2008 01:31PM - edited Nov 25, 2008 02:36PM by Mocity Good idea Nancy... just called my cousin and she is bringing some wine.  I do love my red wine.  I told her to bring a valium too but she said she would have it ready but see if the wine does the trick.  :-)  I am trying to think positive and think this is another step in moving forward and getting this step behind me might help with the stress of waiting for it.

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2012 01:30PM Mocity wrote: I didn't have an onco test because my Onc said it would be high so there was no need.  I was only 37, strong family history and HER2+.... those factors would have affected the test.  So, like Robo47, it wouldn't have changed my treatment recommendation.  My cancer was also very small.  At first we thought it was DCIS but after have a bilateral mastectomy they found a small part that had moved outside the duct.  So chemo, herceptin followed and now hormonal therapy.  Good luck to you!
Posts.Title: oncotype testing for very small IDC dancetrancer doxie

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2008 04:24AM Mocity wrote: Just FYI.... I ended up being in the hospital 2 nights.  I had my surgery Tuesday morning around 9am (Sept 16th) and left around noon on Thursday.  They wanted to release me Wed and I said I wasn't up for it.  I had a bad itching side effect to the morpheine (after being so happy to get the pump) and that kept me up all night before they figured out what was going on.
Posts.Title: How Long in Hospital after Bi-Later with Reconstruction? Mocity mom_of_2

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2011 08:02PM Mocity wrote: I have heard that Livestrong.com will also help get you going in the right direction on resources.
Posts.Title: Need help-just diagnosed with breast cancer Mandy85 Mandy85

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2011 08:09PM Mocity wrote: I had a bilateral mastectomy, then chemo and then herceptin for a year.  I worked the entire time.  Obviously I was out of the office for both surgeries (Bilateral and then the recon) but I worked the whole time I was on chemo.  However, it depends on the job... I am a financial analyst and am at a desk all day which is more do-able than other jobs I'm sure.  It will all depend on the schedule.  I had chemo once a week for 12 weeks and mine took about 1/2 away from work.  Many chemos would require a whole day but some regimines would give you chemo once every three weeks so you could just take a day every 3 weeks.  However, there are ALOT of doctor appts between surgeon, oncologist, chemo, reconstruction, etc.  That would be tough to manage with a new job.  Thankfully my employer at the time was great and flexible and I worked from home in the evenings if I missed alot of work because of appts.  I think you need alot more information before you can really make the decision.  Find out what treatment they are suggesting.  Hang in there
Posts.Title: Job and treatment timeframe yuelin ANA_424

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2009 02:50PM Mocity wrote: I am doing 12 weekly treatments of Taxol+ Herceptin.  Last week I had #9.  Honestly, besides losing my hair, I did pretty well the first 6 weeks (6 treatments).  I was tired and pretty emotional but other than that I thought it went very well.  Then, after #6, I lost steam.  I felt really tired and fatigued.  After #8 I have developed neuropathy in my fingertips and my toenails are turning black and separating from my toes.  My fingernails on my index fingers are hurting too.  I think it just really crept up on me.  I am praying I can get through these last 3 treatments.  The next one (#10) is this Thursday.  With that being said, I would just take all the side effects for what they are and just hope for the best. Everyone is different.  My Onc didn't expect me to have these issues which is one of the reasons we opted for the weekly (to lessen the side effects).  Everyone is different and you could have no problems so why worry about all these things others are going through.  Just take one day at a time and see what happens.  Best of luck, Cristl
Posts.Title: what are side effects of taxol shinypenny shinypenny

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2009 02:52PM Mocity wrote: I re-read you message... about the hair.... I started losing mine around day 15.... I went and had my hairdresser shave it because (for me) just watching it come out and worry about it made me nuts.  I am wearing a wig to work and sleep caps at home.  I just keep telling myself it is temporary and will come back.  I hate it when other people tell me that though.  :-)
Posts.Title: what are side effects of taxol shinypenny shinypenny

Posts.Content: Sep 6, 2008 12:58PM Mocity wrote: My DCIS was discovered by a routine mammogram in May.  It showed up as calcifications and that sent me for more mammogram slides.  Then, I was sent to a breast surgeon, ultrasound and a biopsy.  I then was sent for a MRI.  Right now they are saying my right breast is clear and healthy.  In addition, I tested negative for the BRAC genes regardless of my family history.   I have still opted for a bi-lateral mastectomy (scheduled Sept 16th).  Because of the size I am not a candidate for a lumpectomy on my left breast so I have to do the left one. I feel like the "black cloud" might follow me and personally I don't want to deal with the stress of worrying about the other breast.  I am a "worrier" and just don't want to do it.  Plus, I "feel" like this dx is a red flag and that I should be lucky.  Maybe my Mom started with DCIS but because technology isn't what it is now it wasn't caught early like mine.  It is such a weird position for people to be in.... on one hand I feel like I am "lucky" that it was caught early and then on the other hard I don't feel lucky to still be going in for a bi-lateral mastectomy.  However, I know I am lucky because I saw my Mom and Aunt go through chemo, mastectomy, etc.  Now, my Dad was dx in April with advanced Kidney cancer that has spread to several places.  So, when I think about that I AM lucky but still this is all so hard. Anyway, so, my personal reasoning for the bi-lateral mastectomy is (1) family history (2) don't want to worry about the other breast and not getting detected early enough (like I said... I am a total worrier) (3) I would kick myself if I did get it in the other breast and hadn't taken care of it when I got my "warning" (4) I am 37 and still hoping to get married and have a baby and need this behind me and not rearing its ugly head again (5) my PS said I would get a better "match" doing both (this didn't really play into it but it was another pro on my list) (6) I have to do the left one since I am not a candidate for a lumpectomy Sorry to rant on and on but I hope it helps in some way.  I don't know if it is the "right" decision and I am scared to death but at the same time I feel like it is the "wise" decision for me. Take care, Cristl
Posts.Title: Mastectomy or Not? tiff2008 Fearless_One

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2009 12:19PM Mocity wrote: I am 5 weeks post chemo and just now losing eyelashes..... Can anyone recommend a product?  I read about a couple on here... Revitalash, Li Lash, one on QVC.... was wondering if anyone has found one to work.  I actually bought Revitalash but haven't used it yet.  Also, how long does it take for them to start coming back?? Also, I lost all but 4 toenails.  I am taking Appearex which contains Biotin.  My fingernails are hanging on but separated from the nail bed.  I was wondering if this has happened to anyone else and if so what they did while waiting for regrowth to make them look at least OK.  I am trying to leave them alone as much as possible and the feet are hopeless at this point without big toe nails and wounds where they were.

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2009 12:31AM Mocity wrote: Wow Joanne - we sound pretty similar.  I am so sick of it too.  My fingers and toes feel like they were slammed in a door and now numb and throbbing.  How do we know when it is too much?  I am worried this will be permanent.  I have read for some people it doesn't go away.  I don't know how to know if this is normal or what.  I have an appt Thurs with my Onc but that seems so far away.  I too work full time and haven't missed a day except for the day I go get treatment and I try to work half days on those days.  I am tempted now to ask to work from home.  It hurts to walk because of my toes.  However, I can see how it is probably good in some aspects because it forces me to get dressed and get out of the house.  I also have a rasj on my hands that now has turned into dry skin patches.  Did you have this?  My #10 is this Thursday so I am right behind you.  I will pray the FEC is easier for you than the Taxol. Good luck to you, Cristl

I know it takes a while for your system to recover but this seems crazy.  What would make them keep falling out? Anyone run into this? I finished Herceptin in last month. On your insurance... do you have an out of pocket maximum?  I started getting really freaked out about the costs; however, someone pointed out that my out of pocket max is $3,500.
Posts.Title: Insurance and the healthy breast Journey BethNY

Posts.Content: Mocity wrote: Hi there, I have a question about follow-up care for others in a similar situation......... I am triple positive.  I had extensive DCIS, bi-lateral mastectomy and then they found a small tumor which was .4cm.  My lymph nodes were clear. Because of my age (37), HER+ I am doing chemo + Herceptin.  I am wondering once that is done how does the followup work on making sure it doesn't come back.  After my surgery I was told 90% chance it was gone however 10% chance it could have gone somewhere via the bloodstream.  The Taxol+Herceptin gets this down to 5%-6% I believe. I asked my Onc and he said I would come in for a checkup every 6 months which would include blood work. I am curious what others in the same situation have been told.  Since they don't know if anything traveled in my bloodsteam (lymph nodes clear) and the chemo is a "just in case that happened" how would it be found? Thanks, Cristl Pathology from Bi-Lateral showed IDC (.4cm) in same breast as DCIS and nodes negative Dx 6/25/2008, IDC, <1cm, Stage I, 0/0 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Follow-up After Chemo Mocity Mocity

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2008 12:36PM Mocity wrote: My mom died at 38 from breast cancer and now I have been dx at 37 with early breast cancer.  I just had a bi-lateral and getting ready for chemo.  BUT I also believe there is some gene mutation my family must have.  I tested negative for BRCA 1 and 2; however, I had breast cancer.  My mom had breast cancer, my aunt had breast cancer, uncle had leukemia, grandfather had panceatic cancer and my father has kidney cancer.  There has to be some link.  Just my 2cents.
Posts.Title: Genetic Mutation Question shelt04 pokadot

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2011 03:20PM Mocity wrote: The decisions were the hardest part to me!!  I always pictured that they just tell you what to do.  There was a thread that was called "mushy middle" when I was going through it that has alot of good information about making the decision.  Everyone is different.  I was 37 and was HER2+ which means it is aggressive so even though mine was small there were other risk factors. I REALLY didn't want to do chemo.  I even opted for a bilateral mastectomy but the chemo scared the heck out of me.  In the end I did it.  I didnt want to have any regrets or feel like I didn't do everything I could but like I said that is a personal decision.  I would get a second opinon so you have more advice.  Good luck and hang in there.  Chemo is scary but doable. Do you know if it is HER2+?
Posts.Title: How do you decide on treatment Justina 1Athena1

Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2011 10:40AM Mocity wrote: Hi again,  It is a hard to thing to envision and think about.  I watched my mom go through chemo in the 80's and what I experienced was nothing like that.  Honestly, the first 2 months of treatment were pretty easy for me.  The last couple of months I felt like I had the flu but it wasn't anything like what I was expecting.  I didn't "not do" anything I wanted to do during that time and worked the entire time.  You might find a nice wig you like and my eyelashes didn't fall out until after I finished chemo!  My eyebrows thinning but didn't completely fall out.  If that is the direction you go... you can do it!  Hang in there.....
Posts.Title: How do you decide on treatment Justina 1Athena1

Posts.Content: Mocity wrote: I am going to be starting chemo in the next couple of weeks and now am trying to figure out how to prepare for the hair loss.  My hairdresser mentioned that he would PAY FOR what he is calling a hair system.  I am going to see him Saturday to learn more.  He basically told me he send my hair off and they match it and send him back a deal with my hair texture and color.  It sounds like it is attached to some mesh-type cap.  He actually some way glues or tapes this to my head and it stays on so I don't have to take it on and off.  He actually wears one!  I never knew.  He wears his because of regular male baldness.  Anyway, has anyone ever heard of this????  He says that the hair can grown back underneath and would be fine.  I am worried that it might keep hair from growing back. Thought I would check to see if others have heard of this.
